Judul: Capital   gains  How French Impressionism began   on the banks of the River Thames
Abstrak:
Impressionism   has   much   to   thank   England  for.  The  quintessential  French  movement  was  born  not  on  the  banks  of  the  Seine  but  on  the  banks  of  the  Thames.  In  September  1870,  Monet  moved  to  London  to  escape  conscription  during  the  Franco Prussian War, which had broken out in July. He  was  not  alone  and  joined  a  burgeoning  French  diaspora,  and  he  was  adopted  by  the landscapist Charles-François Daubigny. Daubigny  introduced  him  to  another  dis-
placed  Frenchman,  the  gallery  owner  Paul  Durand-Ruel, with the endorsement, “This artist  will  surpass  us  all.”  The  dealer  took  him  at  his  word,  buying  several  canvases.  A  few  days  later,  an  encouraged  Monet  re-turned  to  the  gallery  with  the  struggling  Camille  Pissarro.  This  chain  of  mutual  assistance  made  in  London  was  at  the  core  of  Impressionism for the next 30 years.
Sumber: New Statesman. 11/3/2017, Vol. 146 Issue 5391, p50-51. 2p. 1 Color Photograph, 1 Illustration
